The last /cry, usually the
largest of the year, will be

of June Week. In order to
obtain a c_olry, each student
must put his name and address

COMMITTEE ANNOUNCES
POSTER COMPETITION
• A poster contest will be held
by the June Week Committee.
The best posters will--serve to
advertise the Johns Hopkins
June Week in Baltimore and
suburbs. Because of so short
a time, the prize will be $15.00
or a June Week ticket. Due
to approaching exams the contest will close this Friday. The
awarding of the prize for the
best poster will be left entirely'
to the June Week Committee.
Everyone is eligible, and the
size, shapes, and colors of the
posters are immaterial. Posters are to be left with Mr.
Meyers at the Post Office.

EDITORIALS

*

*

*

DITING a college paper. is a lot of ,fun. Of course, it has its
Ir dangers and perils also. But, after all, every pleasant task
involves a risk of life and limb. There is always the threat of"the
Black and Blue Jay editor, who is constantly on the verge of assassi•
naiing you in cold blood because of unfavorable reviews of his comic'
literary magazine. Then the Cotillon Club president will dog your
steps with a baseball bat because the paper accidentally announced
that there would be no tea dance after the lacrosse game. Before
the end of the year, practically all of the campus demagogues have
some grievance which must be redressed.
A mid-western journalist once remtuled that "you can't he a
newspaper editor and remain popular." No matter how much tact
one employs, it is practically impossible to avoid ,stepping on someone's toes.- If one undertakes to criticize a campus organization,
the entire roll of members rega,rds the censure as a. personal insult.
If the editor avoids any comment on a• delicate campus situation,
he is called a moral coward and a pussyfooter. If he does attempt
to write about it, he is dubbed a pseudo-Mencken and consigned to
the hottest furnace in Hades. And so it goes—great fun though.

THE COLLEGE YEAR

Steel Structure
to cut the wind

rrHIS writing habit can become an addiction almost as perni•
cious as the practice of taking dope or imbibing alcohol. At
the mere sight of a typewriter, the poor victim will immediately
throw off his coat, roll Up his sleeves" and *commence to thump the
keys like a man possessed. Perhaps he hasn't anything to say—perhaps he has. But whether of not he has any coherent or intelligent
thoughts to present makes little difference. If his Mind, at the time,
is as barren and sterile as a sand dune, he will pound out pages apd
pages of "Now is the time for all good men to'come to the
their party- or "the quick brown hare jumped over the lazy dog;"
in the approved business college fashion.. So when the desk editor of
this issue of the NEWS-LETTER approached me witll a sheepish grin
and asked for a "literary" contribution, the temptation proved entirely too strong to be resisted.. Newspaper editors and operatic
prima donnas have one charactertistic in common. Their "swari
songs" don't mean a thing..

Columnist
Surissin E. Frrzons.ALD, '31

PEED is the keynote of the modern game. The Dayton
string,
Steel Racquet is the fastest in the world. Thin steel
resistance and greater
in a thin steel frame give it 48% less air
strength than any standard wood-and-gut racquet.
That's why a Dayton-driven ball gets over 20% faster.
That's why the Dayton gives you the jump on speedier players.
You've a right to demand facts. Here's the third question
of a series:
Q. How do thinner steel strings affect the life of the ball ?
A. In any-case more than 90% of the wear on a tennis ball
is caused by abrasion of the gritty court, not by the racquet.
The most delicate laboratory scales revealed no difference whatever in the amount of cover removed from two identical set Of
balls given the same number of chop strokes, one set with a
gut, one with .a Dayton Steel Racquet. Dayton Steel Racquet Company, Dayton, Ohio.

of w. A body of learned jurists, working free from care under
ideal conditions, can do much towards making a constructive study
of legal problems. The Institute,Will be of great value,' not only in
defining the law in clearer terms, but in making practical,suggestions
to legislative bodies. Hopkins has done a great service to the country
at large and, incidentally, has greatly increased her own-prestige.
From the undergraduate point of view, the change in the marking system is very significant. The practice of withholding numerical grades on papers and quizes is a step towards abolishing numerical marks entirely. That this state of affairs, when marks shall consist of either "satisfactory" or "non-satisfactory," is desirable is
almost questioned. If every undergraduate were compelled to take
the same examinations and the papers were all graded by the same
instructor under similar conditions, the equity of issuing numerical
grades would be unquestioned. The attempt, however, to correlate
the averages of men taking different courses from different professors
is as unavailing as the Board of Collegiate Studies is at last admitting.
However, the intermediary stage which has been in operation this
winter has proved itself a dismal failure. In three-fourths of the
cases the rule has been disregarded in ;pirit if not in fact and the
total result has been merely to befuddle.a little more the already befuddled undergraduate. The final step, that. ofy doing away with
numerical grades altogether, remains to be taken to convert this
failure into a definite stride forward.
It is with great pleasure and pride that we have watched the
building of the two new additions to the Hopkins' group, Levering
Hall and the new physics building. The expansion of the campus
presents an indication of progress and improvement to the eyes of
the otitside world. The "greater Homewood," until recently nothing
more than an architect's dream to most of us, is now assuming the
aspects of reality.
The undergraduates themselves have not been dormant. The
recent ruling of the Student Activities Council, prohibit,ing a student
from holding more than one of a number of specified positions, is a
praiseworthy attempt to interest more of the undergraduates in
extra-curricular activities. Conversely, it will operate to keep some
men from devoting too much time to these activities. The Athletic
Association Board also passed a wise measure, re-arranging its mess
bership to include the captains and managers of the various teams.
The advice and vote of these men should do much towards standard,
izing the awards of insignia.
The addition of a swimming team to the sports program and
the maintenance of basketball are also encouraging moves. The fact
that the swimming team was arranged for and managed exclusively
by the students, without being subsidized, is of particular interest and
deserves praise. From the point of view of games lost and won, the.
athletic season as a whole can hardly be called a success. Maryland
has beaten us in every sport but tennis; St. Johns swamped the
football team. Yet when the material at hand and the great losses
caused by graduation are considered, the teams' records cannot be
harshly condemned. .
Freshman regulations were a farce. Paddling must be re-instituted, the regulations done away with, or a more workable system of
supervision enforced before the rules will be anything more than a
joke, and a poor one at that.
The periodic periods of excitement again made their scheduled
appearance. Phi Beta Kappa, Omicron Delta Kappa, Scabbard and
Blade, the Tudor and Stuart Club, and the Cane Club all functioned
in the usual manner, providing intermittent topics of conversation
and occasionally producing constructive effort. Banquet season,
parades, and examinations all passed by in the general review, adding their mite of joy and sorrow to the college year.

OPKINS is developing in its midst a worthy successor of Graham McNamee, the famous radio sports announcer. Dave
Kauffman, who starred-on Jay athletic teams, has-turned his talent
to the microphone. At the present timj, he is broadcasting lacrosse
games over Station WFBR.
After listening to Dave giving an account of the Swarthmore
battle, which was staged at Homewood Field several weeks ago, we
have come to the conclusion that lacrosse is not suited to radio broadcasting. The game is so fast moving and the plays are executed with
such astonishing rapidity that it is-difficult to present a comprehensive
word picture.

SYCHOLOGISTS, who profess an interest in the mechanics of
the human mind, would have spent a highly profitable hour in
watching the recent parade of the Tall Cedars. Sober business men
from Lancaster, Pa., and Hagerstown, Md., paraded about the Balti•
.more streets in full fraternal regalia. Most of the uniforms consisted of peaked caps, brocaded vests, baggy pantaloons, white canvas
shoes and colored stockings.
Even more interesting was the crowd on the sfewalk. Children
with balloons clutched in their fists, wailing for ice cream cones.
Corpulent ,matrons bearing market baskets, stuffed with provender
for the family larder. Colored boys, wrestling on the curb-stone and
ceasing their pugilistic exercises only when a band would pass by.
Standing around me were an unusual number of jokesters and
wisecracytrs. When a particularly pompous drum major wotild pass
by one of the witty gentlemen would bawl, "There goes the sap of
_the Tall Cedars." Several counterfeit Indians took part in the performance and one of the wildest looking of the aborigines wore a- pair
of horn-rimmed spectacles. "Oh, look," shouted another smart devil,
"there goes Big Chief Four. Eyes."
Said one woman, "Joe is a perfect scream. That's Evelyn's husband who lives in York. 'Well,' says he, 'where's all them orioles
I've been hearing so much about?' Catch on? Oriole City. Hee,
hee•hee."
•
•
Personally, I'm afraid 'that the name Tall Cedars is a misnomer.
Most of the marchers were short, chubby, pot-bellied gentlemen and
bore no resemblance to the towering pines of the Lebanon forest.

Goucher girls are losing their pul•

there'll be another crop next year, girls. . . . E. E. Thompson gets
part of his June Week trousseau by copping the raffle -prize. . . .
With the announcement that a cafeteria will open next year in Levering Hall, Doc Adams' ice cream cones are becoming a trifle larger.
Undergrads are advised to buy on the rising market. . . George, the
Gilman Hall janitor, declares he is still a Fundamentalist and the

COMMITTEE ANNOUNCES
POSTER COMPETITION
• A poster contest will be held
by the June Week Committee.
The best posters will--serve to
advertise the Johns Hopkins
June Week in Baltimore and
suburbs. Because of so short
a time, the prize will be $15.00
or a June Week ticket. Due
to approaching exams the contest will close this Friday. The
awarding of the prize for the
best poster will be left entirely'
to the June Week Committee.
Everyone is eligible, and the
size, shapes, and colors of the
posters are immaterial. Posters are to be left with Mr.
Meyers at the Post Office.

DITING a college paper. is a lot of ,fun. Of course, it has its
Ir dangers and perils also. But, after all, every pleasant task
involves a risk of life and limb. There is always the threat of"the
Black and Blue Jay editor, who is constantly on the verge of assassi•
naiing you in cold blood because of unfavorable reviews of his comic'
literary magazine. Then the Cotillon Club president will dog your
steps with a baseball bat because the paper accidentally announced
that there would be no tea dance after the lacrosse game. Before
the end of the year, practically all of the campus demagogues have
some grievance which must be redressed.
A mid-western journalist once remtuled that "you can't he a
newspaper editor and remain popular." No matter how much tact
one employs, it is practically impossible to avoid ,stepping on someone's toes.- If one undertakes to criticize a campus organization,
the entire roll of members rega,rds the censure as a. personal insult.
If the editor avoids any comment on a• delicate campus situation,
he is called a moral coward and a pussyfooter. If he does attempt
to write about it, he is dubbed a pseudo-Mencken and consigned to
the hottest furnace in Hades. And so it goes—great fun though.

rrHIS writing habit can become an addiction almost as perni•
cious as the practice of taking dope or imbibing alcohol. At
the mere sight of a typewriter, the poor victim will immediately
throw off his coat, roll Up his sleeves" and *commence to thump the
keys like a man possessed. Perhaps he hasn't anything to say—perhaps he has. But whether of not he has any coherent or intelligent
thoughts to present makes little difference. If his Mind, at the time,
is as barren and sterile as a sand dune, he will pound out pages apd
pages of "Now is the time for all good men to'come to the
their party- or "the quick brown hare jumped over the lazy dog;"
in the approved business college fashion.. So when the desk editor of
this issue of the NEWS-LETTER approached me witll a sheepish grin
and asked for a "literary" contribution, the temptation proved entirely too strong to be resisted.. Newspaper editors and operatic
prima donnas have one charactertistic in common. Their "swari
songs" don't mean a thing..

NDOLISTiDLY the most important step undertaken by Hopkins

during the past year has been the founding of the Institute,
of w. A body of learned jurists, working free from care under
ideal conditions, can do much towards making a constructive study
of legal problems. The Institute,Will be of great value,' not only in
defining the law in clearer terms, but in making practical,suggestions
to legislative bodies. Hopkins has done a great service to the country
at large and, incidentally, has greatly increased her own-prestige.
From the undergraduate point of view, the change in the marking system is very significant. The practice of withholding numerical grades on papers and quizes is a step towards abolishing numerical marks entirely. That this state of affairs, when marks shall consist of either "satisfactory" or "non-satisfactory," is desirable is
almost questioned. If every undergraduate were compelled to take
the same examinations and the papers were all graded by the same
instructor under similar conditions, the equity of issuing numerical
grades would be unquestioned. The attempt, however, to correlate
the averages of men taking different courses from different professors
is as unavailing as the Board of Collegiate Studies is at last admitting.
However, the intermediary stage which has been in operation this
winter has proved itself a dismal failure. In three-fourths of the
cases the rule has been disregarded in ;pirit if not in fact and the
total result has been merely to befuddle.a little more the already befuddled undergraduate. The final step, that. ofy doing away with
numerical grades altogether, remains to be taken to convert this
failure into a definite stride forward.
It is with great pleasure and pride that we have watched the
building of the two new additions to the Hopkins' group, Levering
Hall and the new physics building. The expansion of the campus
presents an indication of progress and improvement to the eyes of
the otitside world. The "greater Homewood," until recently nothing
more than an architect's dream to most of us, is now assuming the
aspects of reality.
The undergraduates themselves have not been dormant. The
recent ruling of the Student Activities Council, prohibit,ing a student
from holding more than one of a number of specified positions, is a
praiseworthy attempt to interest more of the undergraduates in
extra-curricular activities. Conversely, it will operate to keep some
men from devoting too much time to these activities. The Athletic
Association Board also passed a wise measure, re-arranging its mess
bership to include the captains and managers of the various teams.
The advice and vote of these men should do much towards standard,
izing the awards of insignia.
The addition of a swimming team to the sports program and
the maintenance of basketball are also encouraging moves. The fact
that the swimming team was arranged for and managed exclusively
by the students, without being subsidized, is of particular interest and
deserves praise. From the point of view of games lost and won, the.
athletic season as a whole can hardly be called a success. Maryland
has beaten us in every sport but tennis; St. Johns swamped the
football team. Yet when the material at hand and the great losses
caused by graduation are considered, the teams' records cannot be
harshly condemned. .
Freshman regulations were a farce. Paddling must be re-instituted, the regulations done away with, or a more workable system of
supervision enforced before the rules will be anything more than a
joke, and a poor one at that.
The periodic periods of excitement again made their scheduled
appearance. Phi Beta Kappa, Omicron Delta Kappa, Scabbard and
Blade, the Tudor and Stuart Club, and the Cane Club all functioned
in the usual manner, providing intermittent topics of conversation
and occasionally producing constructive effort. Banquet season,
parades, and examinations all passed by in the general review, adding their mite of joy and sorrow to the college year.

OPKINS is developing in its midst a worthy successor of Graham McNamee, the famous radio sports announcer. Dave
Kauffman, who starred-on Jay athletic teams, has-turned his talent
to the microphone. At the present timj, he is broadcasting lacrosse
games over Station WFBR.
After listening to Dave giving an account of the Swarthmore
battle, which was staged at Homewood Field several weeks ago, we
have come to the conclusion that lacrosse is not suited to radio broadcasting. The game is so fast moving and the plays are executed with
such astonishing rapidity that it is-difficult to present a comprehensive
word picture.

SYCHOLOGISTS, who profess an interest in the mechanics of
the human mind, would have spent a highly profitable hour in
watching the recent parade of the Tall Cedars. Sober business men
from Lancaster, Pa., and Hagerstown, Md., paraded about the Balti•
.more streets in full fraternal regalia. Most of the uniforms consisted of peaked caps, brocaded vests, baggy pantaloons, white canvas
shoes and colored stockings.
Even more interesting was the crowd on the sfewalk. Children
with balloons clutched in their fists, wailing for ice cream cones.
Corpulent ,matrons bearing market baskets, stuffed with provender
for the family larder. Colored boys, wrestling on the curb-stone and
ceasing their pugilistic exercises only when a band would pass by.
Standing around me were an unusual number of jokesters and
wisecracytrs. When a particularly pompous drum major wotild pass
by one of the witty gentlemen would bawl, "There goes the sap of
_the Tall Cedars." Several counterfeit Indians took part in the performance and one of the wildest looking of the aborigines wore a- pair
of horn-rimmed spectacles. "Oh, look," shouted another smart devil,
"there goes Big Chief Four. Eyes."
Said one woman, "Joe is a perfect scream. That's Evelyn's husband who lives in York. 'Well,' says he, 'where's all them orioles
I've been hearing so much about?' Catch on? Oriole City. Hee,
hee•hee."
•
•
Personally, I'm afraid 'that the name Tall Cedars is a misnomer.
Most of the marchers were short, chubby, pot-bellied gentlemen and
bore no resemblance to the towering pines of the Lebanon forest.

ITH the approach of examination, chairs in the libiary are
. at a premium. However, it is rumored, that most of the
studying will be done on the night before the ordeal. Editors of
The Blue Blackmail, the sensational campus scandal sheet, report that
the annual expose will be published soon and will make its appearance on Class Day. . . . With the final touches being put on Levering Hall, the' announcement of the complete conversion of the
campus is expected shortly. .
Goucher girls are losing their pul•
chritude if the current isue of Donnybrook Fair may be taken as a
criterion. . . . The telephone service at Vingolf remains as had as
ever. . . . In spite of frantic efforts by the teachers' college coeds,
no engagements to undergraduates have been reported. Oh, well,
there'll be another crop next year, girls. . . . E. E. Thompson gets
part of his June Week trousseau by copping the raffle -prize. . . .
With the announcement that a cafeteria will open next year in Levering Hall, Doc Adams' ice cream cones are becoming a trifle larger.
Undergrads are advised to buy on the rising market. . . George, the
Gilman Hall janitor, declares he is still a Fundamentalist and the
Baptist Church is the only safe road to heaven. . . . Tudor Stuart
Club members prbbably won't see. anything literary about this column. Neither do I.
